Key Arguments: The bill threatens freedom of speech and democratic principles.
It creates a disparity between politicians, journalists, and regular citizens in terms of who can disseminate information.
Excessive fines will lead to more restrictive digital services, limiting free speech.
The bill's broad scope could classify well-intentioned information as misinformation.
Delegating legislative power to private entities is unconstitutional.
The bill impinges on the implied constitutional freedom of political communication.
It assumes government and accredited institutions have sole authority over truth.
The legislation intimidates digital platforms and users, threatening reputational damage and financial penalties.
Notable Quotes: The proposed bill creates a clear distinction between two classes of citizens.
Attempting to accurately discern between truth and falsehood is an arduous task.
The bill assumes that the government and its accredited media and educational institutions possess the sole authority to decide what is true.
The potential expectation for individuals to report on others, reminiscent of Soviet-era tactics, is entirely antithetical to Australian values.
